canonical_explanation.text: Every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force called gravitational force. Newton's universal law of gravitation states that the gravitational force between two objects is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them: F = Gm₁m₂/r². The gravitational constant G = 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg². When an object falls freely under gravity, it experiences acceleration due to gravity (g = 9.8 m/s²). Mass is the amount of matter in a body and remains constant everywhere, while weight is the gravitational force on the body (W = mg) and varies with location. Thrust is the force acting perpendicular to a surface, and pressure is thrust per unit area. Buoyancy is the upward force exerted by a fluid on a submerged object. Archimedes' principle states that the buoyant force equals the weight of fluid displaced.
rules: Universal law of gravitation: F = Gm₁m₂/r².
Acceleration due to gravity: g = 9.8 m/s² (on Earth's surface).
Free fall: motion under gravity alone, with acceleration g.
Mass is constant; weight (W = mg) varies with location.
Weight on moon ≈ 1/6 of weight on Earth.
Pressure = Force / Area; SI unit is Pascal (Pa).
Buoyant force = Weight of displaced fluid (Archimedes' principle).
Object floats if its density is less than fluid density.
Relative density = Density of substance / Density of water.

questions.question_text: The universal law of gravitation was given by:
questions.explanation_correct: Sir Isaac Newton formulated the universal law of gravitation. He proposed that every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Galileo studied motion and falling bodies but did not formulate the law of gravitation. Einstein developed general relativity. Archimedes is known for his principle of buoyancy. Newton formulated the universal law of gravitation.

questions.question_text: According to Newton's universal law of gravitation, the force between two bodies is:

options.text: Directly proportional to the square of the distance
Inversely proportional to the product of masses
Inversely proportional to the square of the distance

questions.explanation_correct: According to Newton's law, the gravitational force F = Gm₁m₂/r². The force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance (r²) between the two bodies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The gravitational force is inversely proportional to r² (not directly proportional), directly proportional to the product of masses (not inversely), and depends on distance. The correct relationship is F ∝ 1/r².

questions.question_text: The value of the universal gravitational constant G is:
questions.explanation_correct: The universal gravitational constant G = 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg². It is a very small number, which is why gravitational force is noticeable only when at least one of the objects has a very large mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 9.8 m/s² is the value of acceleration due to gravity (g), not G. The exponent is negative (10⁻¹¹), not positive. G = 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg².

questions.question_text: If the distance between two bodies is doubled, the gravitational force between them becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: Since F ∝ 1/r², if distance is doubled (r → 2r), the force becomes F/(2²) = F/4, or one-fourth of the original value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The gravitational force follows an inverse square law (F ∝ 1/r²). Doubling the distance means the force reduces by a factor of 4, not 2. It becomes one-fourth.

questions.question_text: If the mass of one of two objects is tripled, the gravitational force between them:
questions.explanation_correct: Since F = Gm₁m₂/r², the force is directly proportional to each mass. Tripling one mass triples the force: F' = G(3m₁)m₂/r² = 3F.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The gravitational force is directly proportional to each mass. Tripling one mass triples the force. It does not become nine times (that would require both masses to be tripled).

questions.question_text: The value of acceleration due to gravity on Earth's surface is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The acceleration due to gravity (g) on Earth's surface is approximately 9.8 m/s². This is the acceleration experienced by any object in free fall near the Earth's surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ is the value of G (gravitational constant), not g. The standard value of g on Earth's surface is approximately 9.8 m/s².

questions.question_text: When an object is in free fall, its acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: In free fall, an object is acted upon only by the force of gravity. Its acceleration equals the acceleration due to gravity, g = 9.8 m/s², directed downward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In free fall (when only gravity acts), the acceleration equals g. It would be less than g only if air resistance or other forces were present. In true free fall, acceleration = g.

questions.question_text: A stone is dropped from a height of 20 m. How long does it take to reach the ground? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Using s = ut + ½gt²: 20 = 0 + ½(10)t² → 20 = 5t² → t² = 4 → t = 2 s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With u = 0, s = ½gt² → t = √(2s/g) = √(40/10) = √4 = 2 s. Other options do not satisfy this equation.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward with a velocity of 30 m/s. What is the maximum height reached? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: At maximum height, v = 0. Using v² = u² − 2gh: 0 = 900 − 20h → h = 45 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v² = u² − 2gh with v = 0: h = u²/(2g) = 900/20 = 45 m. Other options arise from incorrect substitution.

questions.question_text: Mass of a body is:

options.text: The force of gravity on it
The amount of matter contained in it

questions.explanation_correct: Mass is the amount of matter contained in a body. It is a scalar quantity, remains constant everywhere, and is measured in kilograms (kg).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The force of gravity is weight, not mass. Mass does not change on different planets (weight does). Mass is measured in kg, not Newtons. Mass is the amount of matter in a body.

questions.question_text: The weight of an object on the moon is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The acceleration due to gravity on the moon is about 1/6 of that on Earth. Since weight = mg, the weight on the moon is approximately 1/6 of the weight on Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The moon has less mass and a smaller radius than Earth, resulting in g_moon ≈ g_earth/6. Therefore, weight on moon = mg_moon ≈ (1/6)mg_earth.

questions.question_text: An object weighs 60 N on Earth. What is its mass? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Weight = mg → m = W/g = 60/10 = 6 kg. The mass of the object is 6 kg.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using W = mg: m = 60/10 = 6 kg. 600 kg multiplies instead of divides. 60 kg uses g = 1. The correct mass is 6 kg.

questions.question_text: A person weighs 600 N on Earth. What will be their weight on the moon?
questions.explanation_correct: Weight on moon = (1/6) × weight on Earth = 600/6 = 100 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since g on moon is 1/6 of g on Earth, weight on moon = 600/6 = 100 N. Mass remains the same, but weight changes due to different gravitational acceleration.

questions.question_text: Pressure is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Pressure is defined as force (thrust) per unit area: P = F/A. Its SI unit is Pascal (Pa), where 1 Pa = 1 N/m².
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pressure is the ratio of force to area, not the product. P = F/A. Higher force on a smaller area creates more pressure.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of pressure is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of pressure is the Pascal (Pa). 1 Pa = 1 N/m². It is named after the French scientist Blaise Pascal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton is the unit of force, Joule is the unit of energy, and Watt is the unit of power. The SI unit of pressure is the Pascal (Pa).

questions.question_text: A force of 100 N acts on an area of 0.5 m². What is the pressure?
questions.explanation_correct: Pressure = Force / Area = 100 / 0.5 = 200 Pa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P = F/A = 100/0.5 = 200 Pa. 50 Pa would be F × A. The correct pressure is 200 Pa.

questions.question_text: Why do sharp knives cut better than blunt ones?

options.text: Sharp knives have a smaller contact area, producing more pressure
Sharp knives are made of harder material

questions.explanation_correct: A sharp knife has a very thin edge (small area). Since P = F/A, the same force applied over a smaller area produces much greater pressure, making it easier to cut.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The force applied is the same, but the area of a sharp edge is much smaller than a blunt edge. By P = F/A, smaller area means greater pressure, which makes cutting easier.

questions.question_text: Pressure in a liquid at depth h is given by P = ρgh. If the depth is doubled, the pressure:
questions.explanation_correct: Since P = ρgh, pressure is directly proportional to depth. If depth doubles (h → 2h), pressure doubles: P' = ρg(2h) = 2ρgh = 2P.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pressure in a liquid increases linearly with depth (P = ρgh). Doubling the depth doubles the pressure. It is not an inverse-square relationship.

questions.question_text: The upward force exerted by a fluid on a submerged object is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The upward force exerted by a fluid on a submerged (or partially submerged) object is called the buoyant force or upthrust. This force is responsible for making objects feel lighter in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravity acts downward, not upward. Thrust is a general perpendicular force. Friction opposes motion. The upward force by a fluid on a submerged object is specifically called the buoyant force.

questions.question_text: According to Archimedes' principle, the buoyant force on an object submerged in a fluid equals:

options.text: The weight of the fluid displaced

questions.explanation_correct: Archimedes' principle states that the buoyant force acting on a body submerged in a fluid is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force equals the weight of the displaced fluid, not the weight of the object, the volume, or the density. This is Archimedes' principle.

questions.question_text: An object will float in a liquid if:

options.text: Its density is greater than the liquid's density
Its density is less than the liquid's density
Its density equals the liquid's density

questions.explanation_correct: An object floats when its density is less than or equal to the liquid's density. When density equals the liquid, it remains suspended. When less, it floats on the surface. Both conditions allow floating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An object floats when its density is less than the fluid (it rises to the surface) or equal to the fluid (it remains suspended). If density is greater, it sinks.

questions.question_text: A block of wood floats in water but sinks in alcohol. This is because:

options.text: The density of wood is less than water but more than alcohol

questions.explanation_correct: Wood floats in water because its density is less than water's density (1000 kg/m³). It sinks in alcohol because alcohol's density (~789 kg/m³) is less than wood's density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Floating depends on relative densities. Wood's density is between that of alcohol and water: alcohol < wood < water. So wood floats in water but sinks in alcohol.

questions.question_text: The gravitational force between two objects of masses 50 kg and 100 kg placed 1 m apart is: (G = 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg²)
A stone is dropped from a cliff. What is its velocity after 3 seconds of free fall? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Using v = u + gt: v = 0 + 10 × 3 = 30 m/s. The stone reaches a velocity of 30 m/s after 3 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: v = u + gt = 0 + 10(3) = 30 m/s. 45 m/s would be the distance fallen (s = ½gt²), not velocity. The velocity is 30 m/s.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward with velocity 40 m/s. How long does it take to return to the thrower? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Time to reach maximum height: v = u − gt → 0 = 40 − 10t → t = 4 s. Total time = 2 × 4 = 8 s (time to go up equals time to come down).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time to reach the top = u/g = 40/10 = 4 s. Total time of flight = 2 × 4 = 8 s. The ball takes equal time going up and coming down.

questions.question_text: The mass of an object is 10 kg. What is the difference between its weight on Earth and on the moon? (g_Earth = 10 m/s², g_Moon = 1.67 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Weight on Earth = 10 × 10 = 100 N. Weight on Moon = 10 × 1.67 = 16.7 N. Difference = 100 − 16.7 = 83.3 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: W_Earth = mg_E = 100 N, W_Moon = mg_M = 16.7 N. Difference = 100 − 16.7 = 83.3 N. The mass remains 10 kg everywhere.

questions.question_text: A body weighs 50 N in air and 40 N when fully submerged in water. What is the buoyant force?
questions.explanation_correct: Buoyant force = Weight in air − Weight in water = 50 − 40 = 10 N. The water pushes the body upward with a force of 10 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force is the apparent loss in weight: 50 − 40 = 10 N. The body feels 10 N lighter in water due to the upward buoyant force.

questions.question_text: The relative density of a substance is 0.8. It will:
questions.explanation_correct: Relative density 0.8 means the substance's density is 0.8 times the density of water. Since its density is less than water's, it will float.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A relative density less than 1 means the substance is less dense than water. Objects less dense than the surrounding fluid float. Relative density 0.8 < 1, so the substance floats.

questions.question_text: A block of mass 5 kg is placed on a table with a base area of 0.1 m². What is the pressure on the table? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Weight = mg = 5 × 10 = 50 N. Pressure = F/A = 50/0.1 = 500 Pa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Force (weight) = 5 × 10 = 50 N. Pressure = 50/0.1 = 500 Pa. Other options arise from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: If both the masses in Newton's law of gravitation are doubled, the gravitational force:
questions.explanation_correct: F = Gm₁m₂/r². If both masses double: F' = G(2m₁)(2m₂)/r² = 4Gm₁m₂/r² = 4F. The force becomes four times.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When both masses are doubled: F' = G(2m₁)(2m₂)/r² = 4F. The force is proportional to the product of masses, so doubling both gives 2 × 2 = 4 times the original force.

questions.question_text: The gravitational force between two objects is always attractive.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Gravitational force is always attractive. Unlike electric or magnetic forces, gravity only pulls objects toward each other and never repels them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Gravitational force is always an attractive force that pulls two masses toward each other. There is no repulsive gravitational force.

questions.question_text: When an object is taken from Earth to the moon, which quantity remains unchanged?
questions.explanation_correct: Mass remains constant regardless of location because it is the amount of matter in a body. Weight changes because it depends on gravitational acceleration (g), which is different on the moon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weight depends on g (W = mg) and changes with location. Mass is an intrinsic property and does not change. Only mass remains unchanged when moving between Earth and moon.

questions.question_text: In free fall, all objects fall with the same acceleration regardless of their mass.
questions.explanation_correct: True. In the absence of air resistance, all objects experience the same acceleration due to gravity (g ≈ 9.8 m/s²) regardless of their mass. This was demonstrated by Galileo.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. The acceleration due to gravity is independent of mass. In vacuum (true free fall), a feather and a hammer fall at the same rate.

questions.question_text: An iron needle sinks in water, but a ship made of iron floats because the ship displaces more water than its weight.
questions.explanation_correct: True. A ship is hollow and has a large volume, displacing a large amount of water. The weight of water displaced (buoyant force) equals the ship's weight, so it floats. An iron needle has a small volume relative to its mass, so it sinks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The hollow shape of the ship gives it a large effective volume, displacing enough water to create a buoyant force equal to its weight.

questions.question_text: How does pressure in a liquid change with depth?
questions.explanation_correct: Pressure in a liquid increases with depth according to P = ρgh. The deeper the point, the more liquid is above it, exerting greater pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pressure increases linearly with depth (P = ρgh). At greater depths there is more fluid above pressing down. It does not decrease or remain constant.

questions.question_text: The gravitational constant G has the same value everywhere in the universe.
questions.explanation_correct: True. G is a universal constant with the same value (6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg²) everywhere in the universe. It should not be confused with g (acceleration due to gravity), which varies with location.
questions.explanation_incorrect: G is a universal constant and has the same value everywhere. It is different from g, which varies depending on the mass and radius of the celestial body.

questions.question_text: Weight is a vector quantity.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Weight is a force (W = mg) and acts in a specific direction — vertically downward toward the center of the Earth. Since it has both magnitude and direction, it is a vector quantity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weight is indeed a vector quantity because it is a force that has both magnitude (mg) and direction (downward, toward Earth's center).

questions.question_text: The correct formula for Newton's universal law of gravitation is:
questions.explanation_correct: The universal law of gravitation is F = Gm₁m₂/r², where F is gravitational force, G is the gravitational constant, m₁ and m₂ are the masses, and r is the distance between them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The force is inversely proportional to r² (not r), directly proportional to the product m₁m₂ (not the sum), and G multiplies in the numerator. The correct formula is F = Gm₁m₂/r².

questions.question_text: The weight of a body is given by the formula W = ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Weight (W) equals mass (m) multiplied by acceleration due to gravity (g). W = mg. On Earth, g ≈ 9.8 m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'mg'. Weight is the product of mass and acceleration due to gravity.

questions.question_text: The buoyant force on an object is equal to the weight of the ___ displaced by it.
questions.explanation_correct: According to Archimedes' principle, the buoyant force equals the weight of the fluid displaced by the submerged object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fluid'. Archimedes' principle states that the buoyant force equals the weight of the displaced fluid (liquid or gas).

questions.question_text: The pressure at depth h in a liquid of density ρ is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The pressure at depth h in a liquid is P = ρgh, where ρ is the density of the liquid, g is acceleration due to gravity, and h is the depth below the surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula uses density (ρ), not mass (m). The three quantities ρ, g, and h are all multiplied together. P = ρgh shows that pressure increases linearly with depth.

questions.question_text: Relative density of a substance = Density of substance / Density of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Relative density is the ratio of the density of a substance to the density of water (1000 kg/m³). It is a dimensionless quantity with no units.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'water'. Relative density compares a substance's density to water's density. Since it is a ratio, it has no units.

questions.question_text: A stone is thrown vertically upward with a velocity of 10 m/s. What is the total distance covered when it returns to the starting point? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Maximum height h = u²/(2g) = 100/20 = 5 m. Total distance = up + down = 5 + 5 = 10 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: h = u²/(2g) = 100/20 = 5 m. The stone goes up 5 m and comes back down 5 m, so total distance = 10 m.

questions.question_text: A woman weighing 500 N stands on one foot of area 100 cm². What pressure does she exert on the ground?
questions.explanation_correct: Area = 100 cm² = 100 × 10⁻⁴ m² = 0.01 m². Pressure = F/A = 500/0.01 = 50000 Pa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convert area: 100 cm² = 0.01 m². P = 500/0.01 = 50000 Pa. Common errors include not converting cm² to m².

questions.question_text: A body has volume 100 cm³ and is fully submerged in water. What is the buoyant force acting on it? (Density of water = 1 g/cm³, g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Mass of water displaced = volume × density = 100 cm³ × 1 g/cm³ = 100 g = 0.1 kg. Buoyant force = weight of water displaced = 0.1 × 10 = 1 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Volume of water displaced = 100 cm³. Mass = 100 g = 0.1 kg. Buoyant force = mg = 0.1 × 10 = 1 N.

questions.question_text: What keeps the moon in orbit around the Earth?

options.text: The gravitational force of Earth on the moon

questions.explanation_correct: The gravitational force between the Earth and the moon keeps the moon in orbit. This gravitational pull provides the centripetal force needed for the moon's circular (elliptical) motion around the Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The moon stays in orbit due to Earth's gravitational attraction providing the centripetal force. Inertia alone would make the moon move in a straight line. Magnetic force and solar wind are not responsible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about mass and weight is correct?

options.text: Mass and weight are the same thing
Mass remains constant but weight varies with gravity

questions.explanation_correct: Mass is the amount of matter and remains constant everywhere. Weight is the gravitational force (W = mg) and varies depending on the value of g. Mass is in kg, weight is in N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mass and weight are different. Mass (in kg) is constant; weight (in N) varies with gravity. They are not the same, mass is not in Newtons, and weight is not in kilograms.

questions.question_text: Why do dams have thicker walls at the base?

options.text: Because pressure of water increases with depth
Because water is colder at the base

questions.explanation_correct: Water pressure increases with depth (P = ρgh). At the base of a dam, the pressure is maximum because the depth is greatest. Thicker walls at the base can withstand this higher pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since P = ρgh, pressure increases with depth. The base of a dam experiences the maximum water pressure, so it needs thicker walls to withstand it.

questions.question_text: The acceleration due to gravity on Earth's surface is approximately ___ m/s².
questions.explanation_correct: The acceleration due to gravity (g) on the Earth's surface is approximately 9.8 m/s². It is the acceleration experienced by objects in free fall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '9.8'. The value of g on Earth's surface is approximately 9.8 m/s² (often rounded to 10 m/s² for calculations).

questions.question_text: A substance with relative density greater than 1 will ___ in water.
questions.explanation_correct: If the relative density is greater than 1, the substance is denser than water. A denser object sinks in water because the buoyant force is less than its weight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sink'. Relative density > 1 means the substance is denser than water, so it sinks.
